main_text:
Take a sentence in the indicative mood, suitable for making a
statement: “We’ll be home by ten”, “Tom cooked
the dinner”. Attach a conditional clause to it, and you have a
sentence which makes a conditional statement: “We’ll be
home by ten if the train is on time”, “If Mary
didn’t cook the dinner, Tom cooked it”. A conditional
sentence “If \(A, C\)” or “\(C\) if \(A\)”
thus has two contained sentences or sentence-like clauses. \(A\) is
called the antecedent, \(C\) the consequent. If you understand \(A\)
and \(C\), and you have mastered the conditional construction (as we
all do at an early age), you understand “If \(A, C\)”.
What does “if” mean? Consulting the dictionary yields
“on condition that; provided that; supposing that”. These
are adequate synonyms. But we want more than synonyms. A theory of
conditionals aims to give an account of the conditional construction
which explains when conditional judgements are acceptable, which
inferences involving conditionals are good inferences, and why this
linguistic construction is so important. Despite intensive work of
great ingenuity, this remains a highly controversial subject.
